'''Dixie Alley''' is a nickname sometimes given to areas of the [[southern United States]] that are particularly vulnerable to strong or violent [[tornado]]es.<ref name="redefinealleys">{{cite news|last=Cox|first=John D.|publisher=[[Discovery Channel]]|url=http://news.discovery.com/earth/redefining-tornado-alleys.html|title=Redefining Tornado Alleys|date=April 27, 2010|accessdate=March 1, 2012}}</ref> This is distinct from the better known [[Tornado Alley]] and has a high frequency of strong, long-track tornadoes that move at higher speeds (50+ miles per hour). The term was coined by [[Storm Prediction Center|NSSFC]] Director Allen Pearson after witnessing a tornado outbreak which included more than 9 long-track, violent tornadoes that killed 121 on February 21, 1971. <ref>{{cite news|last=Rice|first=Doyle|publisher=[[USA Today]]|url=https://www.usatoday.com/weather/storms/tornadoes/2011-04-25-tornado-dixie-alley.htm|title=Dixie Alley may see more tornado action than even Tornado Alley|date=April 26, 2011|accessdate=March 1, 2012}}</ref> The specific characteristics of the Southeast led to [[VORTEX projects|VORTEX-SE]], a field project studying [[tornadogenesis]], diagnosis and forecasting, in addition to social science implications, and examines both [[supercell]]ular tornadoes and those resulting from [[squall line|quasi-linear convective system]] (QLCS) thunderstorm structures.<ref>[https://www.nssl.noaa.gov/projects/vortexse/ VORTEX Southeast]</ref>
== Geography == [[File:DixieAlleymap.png|thumb|The ''Dixie Alley'' region indicated by red shaded area.]]
Dixie Alley includes much of the area of the lower [[Mississippi Valley]].<ref>{{cite news|last=Douglas|first=Paul|publisher=[[Star Tribune]]|url=http://www.startribune.com/blogs/92382839.html|title=Deadlier than Tornado Alley: "Dixie Alley"|date=April 28, 2010|accessdate=March 1, 2012}}</ref> It stretches from eastern [[Texas]] and [[Arkansas]] across [[Louisiana]], [[Mississippi]], [[Tennessee]], [[Alabama]], [[Georgia (U.S. state)|Georgia]], to upstate [[South Carolina]] and western [[North Carolina]]; the area reaches as far north as southeast [[Missouri]] and southwest [[Kentucky]].<ref>{{cite news|last=|first=|publisher=[[Atlanta Journal-Constitution]]|url=http://www.ajc.com/news/new-study-puts-metro-501023.html|title=New study puts metro Atlanta in ‘Dixie Alley' for tornadoes|date=April 28, 2010|accessdate=March 1, 2012}}</ref> Another source places all of Arkansas within Dixie Alley.<ref>{{cite techreport |url=http://www.fmglobal.com/research-and-resources/fm-global-data-sheets |title=Wind Design |number=Data Sheet 1-28 |institution=[[FM Global]] |date=October 2016 |page=97}}</ref>
Although tornadoes are less frequent in these states than they are in the southern Plains, the southeastern states have had more tornado-related deaths than any of the Plains states (excluding [[Texas]]). This is in part due to the relatively high number of strong/violent long tracked tornadoes and higher population density of this region, as well as the Southern United States having the highest percentage of [[manufactured homes]] in the US, where 63% of the overall tornado-related fatalities occur.<ref name="supertues08">{{cite web|last=Hayes|first=John L.|publisher=[[NOAA]]|url=http://www.nws.noaa.gov/om/assessments/pdfs/super_tuesday.pdf|title=Service Assessment on the Super Tuesday Tornado Outbreak of February 5-6, 2008|date=March 2009|accessdate=March 1, 2012}}</ref> According to the [[National Climatic Data Center]], for the period January 1, 1950 – October 31, 2006, Alabama and [[Kansas]] received the largest amount of [[Fujita scale|F5]] tornadoes. Complicating matters is that tornadoes are rarely visible in this area, as they are more likely to be rain-wrapped, embedded in shafts of heavy rain, and that the hilly [[topography]] and heavily forested landscape makes them difficult to see.<ref name="supertues08"/>
== Prevalent tornado characteristics == [[File:Tornado in Mississippi on December 23, 2015.jpg|thumb|Tornado in Mississippi, located in Dixie Alley, obscured by trees and featuring a notably low, rugged base.]] Dixie Alley is part of a region of enhanced tornadic activity extending between the Appalachian and Rocky Mountains<ref>{{cite journal |last = Dixon |first = P. Grady |author2 = A. E. Mercer |author3 = J. Choi |author4 = J. S. Allen |title = Tornado Risk Analysis: Is Dixie Alley an Extension of Tornado Alley? |journal = Bull. Amer. Meteor. Soc. |volume = 92 |issue = 4 |pages = 433–441 |date = 2011 |doi = 10.1175/2010BAMS3102.1 }}</ref>, but tornadoes and outbreaks in the Dixie Alley region exhibit some statistically distinguishable characteristics than the more well known Tornado Alley.<ref>{{cite journal |last = Gagan |first = John P. |author2 = A. Gerard |author3 = J. Gordon |title = A Historical and Statistical Comparison of "Tornado Alley" to "Dixie Alley" |journal = NWA Digest |volume = 13 |issue = 2 |pages = 145–155 |date = 2010 |url = http://nwafiles.nwas.org/digest/papers/2010/Vol34No2/Pg145-Gagan-etal.pdf |doi = |access-date = }}</ref> Tornadic storms in Dixie Alley are most often [[Supercell#High Precipitation (HP)|high precipitation supercells]] due to an increase of moisture from proximity to the nearby [[Gulf of Mexico]]. The Dixie Alley tornadoes accompanying the HP supercells are often partially or fully wrapped in rain visually impairing the tornadoes to storm [[storm spotting|spotters]] and [[storm chasing|chasers]], law enforcement, and the public.<ref name="supertues08"/><ref>{{cite web|work=University of Alabama Birmingham|url=http://www.uab.edu/icrc/tornado_helmet_com.html|title=Safety Helmets: A Practical, Inexpensive Solution for Reducing the Risk of Head Injuries Resulting from Tornadoes|date=|accessdate=February 23, 2012}}</ref> Increases of warmth and [[Convective instability|instability]] in conjunction with strong [[wind shear]] in the Dixie Alley region impacts the times when tornadoes form. In the traditional Tornado Alley, tornadoes most often form from the mid afternoon to early evening. Dixie Alley's instability can be maintained long after sunset due to being adjacent to the Gulf, increasing the frequency of intense nighttime and early morning tornadoes.<ref name="supertues08"/> There is also a less focused tornado season which tends to be most active in early spring and late autumn but can continue throughout the winter and into late spring, which can lead to complacency among residents of the region. The region often is subject to tornadoes much earlier than the general national peak from May and June, usually from February to Mid-April,<ref>{{cite news|last=Saslow|first=Rachel|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/national/tornado-season-is-at-its-height-in-dixie-alley/2011/04/28/AF18NA6E_story.html|title=Tornado season is at its height in ‘Dixie Alley’|date=April 28, 2011|accessdate=March 1, 2012|work=The Washington Post}}</ref> and several notorious outbreaks have struck during the late winter and early spring and also in late fall.<ref name="supertues08"/> The complacency situation was noted after the [[2008 Super Tuesday tornado outbreak]] in February 2008 that hit the Dixie Alley killing 57 people, many people indicated that they had underestimated the threat of severe weather on that day since it was well before the peak of tornado season.<ref name="supertues08"/>
Variations in [[climate pattern]]s and [[teleconnection]]s, such as the [[El Niño–Southern Oscillation]] (ENSO) can also have significant impacts on tornadic activity in the region from year to year. [[Climate change]] is also expected to affect tornado activity in the region.<ref>{{cite journal |last = Strader |first = Stephen M. |author2 = W. S. Ashley |author3 = T. J. Pingel |author4 = A. J. Krmenec |title = Projected 21st century changes in tornado exposure, risk, and disaster potential |journal = Climatic Change |volume = 141 |issue = 2 |pages = 301–313 |date = 2017 |doi = 10.1007/s10584-017-1905-4 }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last = Strader |first = Stephen M. |author2 = W. S. Ashley |author3 = T. J. Pingel |author4 = A. J. Krmenec |title = Observed and Projected Changes in United States Tornado Exposure |journal = Wea. Climate Soc. |volume = 9 |issue = 2 |pages = 109–123 |date = 2017 |doi = 10.1175/WCAS-D-16-0041.1 }}</ref>
== Notable outbreaks == Dixie Alley has been subject to numerous [[tornado outbreak]]s throughout history, including very intense outbreaks and those of very large spatial and temporal extent. Notorious outbreaks affecting the region include: the [[Great Natchez Tornado]], the [[1884 Enigma tornado outbreak]], the [[April 1924 tornado outbreak]], the [[1932 Deep South tornado outbreak]], the [[1936 Tupelo-Gainesville tornado outbreak]], the [[April 1957 Southeastern tornado outbreak]], the [[1984 Carolinas tornado outbreak]], and the [[November 1992 tornado outbreak]]. The [[1974 Super Outbreak]] also hit the area very hard, producing multiple F5 tornadoes in Alabama, and F4 tornadoes in North Georgia and the Appalachian southwest of North Carolina. More recently the region was hit by the [[2008 Super Tuesday tornado outbreak]] followed by the [[tornado outbreak of April 14–16, 2011]], the deadliest since the 2008 outbreak.<ref name="supertues08"/> Two weeks after the April 14–16 event, Dixie Alley was the epicenter of the [[2011 Super Outbreak]], which was the largest tornado outbreak ever recorded, as well as the fourth-deadliest outbreak in United States history, with over 300 people dead.<ref name="2011super">{{cite web|url=http://www.noaanews.noaa.gov/april_2011_tornado_information.html|title=April 2011 tornado information|date=May 9, 2011|work=[[NOAA]]|publisher=[[USA.gov]]|accessdate=May 16, 2011}}</ref>
== See also == * [[List of tornadoes and tornado outbreaks]] * [[Tornado climatology]] * [[Tornado Alley]] * [[Hurricane Alley]] * [[Hailstorm Alley]]

'''EfficientDynamics''' is a set of technologies that are defined by [[BMW]] in its products to maximise performance, reduce CO2 emissions and reduce fuel consumption.<ref>{{Cite web|title = BMW EfficientDynamics|url = http://www.bmw.com/com/en/insights/technology/efficientdynamics/2015/index.html|website = www.bmw.com|accessdate = 2015-05-30|first = BMW|last = AG}}</ref> * Common rail injection for diesel engines.<ref>{{Cite web|title=BMW 5 Series Gran Turismo : Common rail |url=http://www.bmw.com.au/com/en/newvehicles/5series/gran_turismo/2009/allfacts/effdyn/common_rail.html |website=www.bmw.com.au |accessdate=2015-05-30 |first=Interone |last=GmbH |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121017202443/http://bmw.com.au/com/en/newvehicles/5series/gran_turismo/2009/allfacts/effdyn/common_rail.html |archivedate=2012-10-17 |df= }}</ref> * Stop start [[engine]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = BMW EfficientDynamics : Auto Start Stop function|url = http://www.bmw.com/com/en/insights/technology/efficient_dynamics/phase_2/technologies/auto_start_stop.html|website = www.bmw.com|accessdate = 2015-05-30|first = Interone|last = GmbH}}</ref> * brake regeneration <ref>{{Cite web|title = BMW EfficientDynamics : Brake Energy Regeneration|url = http://www.bmw.com/com/en/insights/technology/efficient_dynamics/phase_2/technologies/brake_energy_regeneration.html|website = www.bmw.com|accessdate = 2015-05-30|first = Interone|last = GmbH}}</ref> * air vent control <ref>{{Cite web|title = BMW EfficientDynamics : Air vent control|url = http://www.bmw.com/com/en/insights/technology/efficient_dynamics/phase_2/technologies/air_vent_control.html|website = www.bmw.com|accessdate = 2015-05-30|first = Interone|last = GmbH}}</ref> * electric power steering<ref>{{Cite web|title = BMW EfficientDynamics : Electric Power Steering|url = http://www.bmw.com/com/en/insights/technology/efficient_dynamics/phase_2/technologies/electric_power_steering.html|website = www.bmw.com|accessdate = 2015-05-30|first = Interone|last = GmbH}}</ref>
== Common rail injection == BMW's [[common rail]] injection involves managing the fuel injection at every stage from pre injection to delivery with one common rail. This improves fuel delivery and power delivery.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.bmw.com/com/en/insights/technology/technology_guide/articles/common_rail_fuel_injection.html|title=BMW Technology Guide : Common rail injection system|last=GmbH|first=Interone Worldwide|website=www.bmw.com|access-date=2016-06-09}}</ref>
== Stop start engine == The stop-start feature will automatically switch off the engine when the car is idling at a complete stop. This reduces fuel consumption while idling for extended periods. The engine automatically switch on when the brake pedal is released, turning your steering wheel (which activates power steering), or shifting from park.
== Brake regeneration == The alternator is charging the battery only when the car is braking, coasting or decelerating<ref>http://www.bmw.com/com/en/insights/technology/technology_guide/articles/mm_brake_energy_regeneration.html</ref>
== Air vent control == The [[air vents]] in front of the radiator grille will open up to allow for air to cool. They will automatically close if it is not in use, reducing air resistance and fuel consumption.
== Electric power steering == The [[power steering]] is only active when the steering wheel is turning. If it is kept in a constant location or place, the electric power is inactive.
== References == <references />

In [[mechanics]], the '''flexural modulus''' or '''bending modulus'''<ref>{{citation |author1=Zweben, C. |author2=W. S. Smith |author3=M. W. Wardle |last-author-amp=yes | title = Test methods for fiber tensile strength, composite flexural modulus, and properties of fabric-reinforced laminates | journal = Composite Materials: Testing and Design (Fifth Conference) | publisher = ASTM International | year = 1979}}</ref> is an intensive property that is computed as the ratio of [[stress (physics)|stress]] to [[Strain (materials science)|strain]] in [[Flexural strength|flexural deformation]], or the tendency for a material to resist bending. It is determined from the slope of a stress-strain curve produced by a flexural test (such as the [[ASTM]] D790), and uses units of force per area.<ref>{{citation | title = D790-03: Standard Test Methods for Flexural Properties of Unreinforced and Reinforced Plastics and Electrical Insulating Materials | publisher = ASTM International | location = West Conshohocken, PA | year = 2003}}</ref>
[[File:Flexural modulus measurement.png|thumb|upright=2.0|Flexural modulus measurement]] For a 3-point test of a rectangular beam behaving as an isotropic linear material, where ''w'' and ''h'' are the width and height of the beam, ''I'' is the second moment of area of the beam's cross-section, ''L'' is the distance between the two outer supports, and ''d'' is the deflection due to the load ''F'' applied at the middle of the beam, the flexural modulus:<ref>{{citation |author1=Zweben, C. |author2=W. S. Smith |author3=M. W. Wardle |last-author-amp=yes | title = Test methods for fiber tensile strength, composite flexural modulus, and properties of fabric-reinforced laminates | journal = Composite Materials: Testing and Design (Fifth Conference) | publisher = ASTM International | year = 1979}}</ref> :<math> E_{\mathrm{bend}} = \frac {L^3 F}{4 w h^3 d} </math> From elastic beam theory :<math>d = \frac {L^3 F}{48 I E } </math> and for rectangular beam : <math> I = \frac{1}{12}wh^3 </math>
thus <math>E_{\mathrm{bend}} = E </math> ([[Elastic modulus]])
Ideally, flexural or bending [[modulus of elasticity]] is equivalent to the tensile modulus ([[Young's modulus]]) or compressive modulus of elasticity. In reality, these values may be different, especially for [[polymer]]s.

{{Infobox company | name = Flood Brothers Disposal | logo = | caption = | type = Private | foundation = {{Start date|1930}}:<ref>{{cite web|last=|first=|title=History of Flood Brothers|url=http://floodbrothersdisposal.com/about-us/history/#sthash.pH5aXJd3.dpbs|work=Flood Brothers Disposal Homepage}}</ref> | founder = | defunct = <!-- {{End date|YYYY|MM|DD}} --> | location_city = [[Oakbrook Terrace, IL]] | location_country = United States | locations = | area_served = Chicago & Suburbs | key_people = The Flood Family, Owners | industry = [[Waste management]] | products = | services = Commercial and residential waste management, recycling services, dumpster and roll-off container rental }}
'''Flood Brothers Disposal''' is a family-owned waste management and recycling service based in [[Oakbrook Terrace, IL]] with offices in [[Chicago, IL]]. Flood Brothers Disposal's service area extends to 150 or more communities in the Chicago area. The business is a member of the National Solid Waste Management Association, the Solid Waste Agency of Northern Cook County,<ref>{{cite web|title=Solid Waste/Recycling Haulers|url=http://swancc.org/swancc-solid-waste-recycling-hauler-contracts|work=SWANCC Website}}</ref> the National Recycling Coalition, the Illinois Food Scrap Coalition,<ref>{{cite web|title=IFSC Members List|url=http://illinoiscomposts.org/ifsc-members/member-list|work=IFSC Website }}</ref> the National Waste & Recycling Association,<ref>{{cite web|title=NWRA Official Website|url=https://wasterecycling.org/|publisher=National Waste & Recycling Association}}</ref> and the Illinois Recycling Association.<ref>{{cite web|title=Flood Brothers Disposal|url=http://www.illinoisrecycles.org/2014/11/flood-brothers-disposal-co/|work=Illinois Recycling Association Website}}</ref>
==History==
Flood Brothers Disposal started operations with one truck and one employee, at 139 N. Clark St. in Chicago, Illinois. In 1963, the main center of operations moved to 5435 W. Chicago Ave. From 1970 to 1977, the company continued expansion and moved to several additional locations, eventually settling at 4827 W. Harrison St. in Chicago, where the company is presently based.
In 1988, the company expanded to include a fully automated recycling center, and in 1990, became the first licensed special waste hauler in the Chicago community. In 1996, Flood Brothers Disposal opened an additional facility in Carol Stream, Illinois. As of today, Flood Brothers Disposal services more than 150 communities in the Chicago area.<ref>{{cite web|title=Flood Brothers History|url=http://floodbrothersdisposal.com/about-us/history/|work=Flood Brothers Disposal Website}}</ref>
==Areas of Operation==
Flood Brothers Disposal provides service in 150 communities in the Chicago area as of present day<ref>{{cite web|title=Communities We Serve|url=http://floodbrothersdisposal.com/about-us/communities-served/|work=Flood Brothers Disposal Website }}</ref>
==Awards==
In 2015, Flood Brothers Disposal was named "2015 Illinois Medium Family Business of the Year" by [[Loyola University Chicago|Loyola University]]'s [[Quinlan School of Business]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Illinois Family Business of the Year Awards|url=http://www.luc.edu/quinlan/fbc/fboy.shtml|work=Quinlan School of Business Official Website}}</ref>

[[File:PetrifiedWood.jpg|right|thumb|Petrified softwood]] [[File:Clouseup of Wood Fossil-Thirvakkarai, Tamil Nadu.jpg|thumb|Fossil wood from the Pliocene in Thirvakkarai, [[Tamil Nadu]]]] {{Paleontology}}
'''Fossil wood''' is [[wood]] that is preserved in the [[fossil record]]. Over time the wood will usually be the part of a plant that is best preserved (and most easily found). Fossil wood may or may not be [[petrified wood|petrified]]. The study of fossil wood is sometimes called palaeoxylology, with a "palaeoxylologist" somebody who studies fossil wood.
The fossil wood may be the only part of the plant that has been preserved, with the rest of the plant completely unknown:<ref name="strauss">{{cite web |url=http://www.edstrauss.com/pwoodfx.html |title=Petrified Wood from Western Washington |author=Ed Strauss |year=2001 |accessdate=April 8, 2011 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101211224655/http://www.edstrauss.com/pwoodfx.html |archivedate=December 11, 2010 |df= }}</ref> therefore such wood may get a special kind of [[botanical name]]. This will usually include "xylon" and a term indicating its presumed affinity, such as ''[[Araucarioxylon arizonicum|Araucarioxylon]]'' (wood of ''[[Araucaria]]'' or some related genus), ''[[Palmoxylon]]'' (wood of an indeterminate [[Arecaceae|palm]]), or ''Castanoxylon'' (wood of an indeterminate [[Castanopsis|chinkapin]]).<ref name="stewart">{{cite book |author1=Wilson Nichols Stewart |author2=Gar W. Rothwell |title =Paleobotany and the evolution of plants |publisher =Cambridge University Press |edition=2 |year =1993 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=Fhm-oed74JgC&dq=naming+fossil+wood&source=gbs_navlinks_s |isbn =978-0-521-38294-6 |page=31 }}</ref>
==Types==
===Petrified wood=== {{Main|Petrified wood}} Petrified wood are fossils of wood that have turned to stone through the process of [[permineralization]]. All organic materials are replaced with minerals while maintaining the original structure of the wood.
The most notable example is the [[Petrified Forest National Park|petrified forest]] in [[Arizona]].<ref name="nps">{{cite web |url=http://www.nps.gov/pefo/index.htm |title=Petrified Forest National Park |accessdate=April 8, 2011 |publisher=National Park Service, US Department of the Interior }}</ref>
===Mummified wood=== Mummified wood are fossils of wood that have not permineralized.<ref name="strauss2">{{cite web |url=http://www.canadiangeographic.ca/blog/posting.asp?ID=414 |title=Mummified Forest Shows Effect of Changing Climate |author=Kelly Greig |date=January 17, 2011 |accessdate=April 8, 2011 |publisher=Canadian Geographic |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110205052304/http://canadiangeographic.ca/blog/posting.asp?ID=414 |archivedate=February 5, 2011 |df= }}</ref> They are formed when trees are buried rapidly in dry cold or hot environments. They are valued in paleobotany because they retain original cells and tissues capable of being examined with the same techniques used with extant plants in [[dendrology]].<ref name="taylor">{{cite book |author1=Thomas N. Taylor |author2=Edith L. Taylor |author3=Michael Krings |title =Paleobotany: the biology and evolution of fossil plants |publisher =Academic Press |year =2009 |isbn =978-0-12-373972-8 |page=33 }}</ref>
Notable examples include the mummified forests in [[Ellesmere Island]]<ref name="lemonick">{{cite web |url=http://www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,962379-1,00.html |title=Science: Unearthing a Frozen Forest |author1=Michael D. Lemonick |author2=Courtney Tower |author3=Diane Webster |date=September 22, 1986 |accessdate=April 8, 2011 |publisher=Time }}</ref> and [[Axel Heiberg Island]].<ref name="hsu">{{cite web |url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/40707755/ns/technology_and_science-science/ |title=2-million-year-old 'mummy trees' reveal harsh climate |author=Jeremy Hsu |date=December 16, 2010 |accessdate=April 8, 2011 |publisher=MSNBC }}</ref>
===Submerged forests=== {{Main|Submerged forest}} Submerged forests are remains of trees submerged by [[marine transgression]]. They are important in determining sea level rise since the [[last glacial period]].<ref name="bird">{{cite book |author=Eric Charles Frederick Bird |title =Coastal geomorphology: an introduction |publisher =John Wiley and Sons |year =2008 |isbn =978-0-470-51729-1 |page=52 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=-YX0mWBpjGkC&dq=submerged+forest&source=gbs_navlinks_s }}</ref>
==See also== *[[Dendrochronology]] *[[Paleobotany]] *[[Lignite#Types|Xyloid lignite]]

In [[fixed-wing aircraft]], '''ground effect''' is the increased [[lift (force)]] and decreased [[aerodynamic drag]] that an aircraft's [[wing]]s generate when they are close to a fixed surface.<ref name="Irving Gleim">Gleim 1982, p. 94.</ref> When landing, ground effect can give the pilot the feeling that the aircraft is "floating". When taking off, ground effect may temporarily reduce the [[stall speed]]. The pilot can then fly just above the runway while the aircraft accelerates in ground effect until a safe [[v speeds|climb speed]] is reached.<ref name="Flight theory and aerodynamics">Dole 2000, p. 70.</ref>
{{TOC limit|limit=2}}
==Principle of ground effect==
[[File:Flügel ohne Bodeneffekt.png|thumb|Normal lift: {{colorbox|lightyellow}} high pressure; {{colorbox|lightblue}} low pressure.]] [[File:Positiver Bodeneffekt.png|thumb|Lift in ground effect due to the increase in high pressure under the wing.]] [[File:El efecto suelo.ogg|thumb|Ground effect]]
When an aircraft flies at a ground level approximately at or below the length of the aircraft's [[wingspan]] or helicopter's rotor diameter, there occurs, depending on airfoil and aircraft design, an often noticeable ground effect. This is caused primarily by the ground interrupting the [[wingtip vortices]] and [[downwash]] behind the wing. When a wing is flown very close to the ground, wingtip vortices are unable to form effectively due to the obstruction of the ground. The result is lower [[induced drag]], which increases the [[speed]] and [[lift (force)|lift]] of the aircraft.<ref>''Aerodynamics for Naval Aviators.'' RAMESH TAAL, HOSUR, VIC. Australia: Aviation Theory Centre, 2005.</ref><ref name="Pilot's Encyclopedia of Aeronautical Knowledge">''Pilot's Encyclopedia of Aeronautical Knowledge'' 2007, pp. 3-7, 3-8.</ref>
A wing generates lift by deflecting the oncoming airmass (relative wind) downward.<ref>"Lift from Flow Turning". NASA Glenn Research Center. Retrieved July 7, 2009.</ref> The deflected or "turned" flow of air creates a resultant force on the wing in the opposite direction (Newton's 3rd law). The resultant force is identified as lift. Flying close to a surface increases air pressure on the lower wing surface, nicknamed the "ram" or "cushion" effect, and thereby improves the aircraft lift-to-drag ratio. The lower/nearer the wing is with regards to the ground, the more pronounced the ground effect becomes. While in the ground effect, the wing requires a lower [[angle of attack]] to produce the same amount of lift. If the angle of attack and [[velocity]] remain constant, an increase in the lift coefficient ensues,<ref name="Pilot pp.3-8">Dole 2000, pp. 3–8.</ref> which accounts for the "floating" effect. Ground effect also alters [[thrust]] versus velocity, where reduced induced drag requires less thrust in order to maintain the same velocity.<ref name="Pilot pp.3-8"/>
[[Low wing|Low winged aircraft]] are more affected by ground effect than [[high wing]] aircraft.<ref>Flight theory and aerodynamics, p. 70</ref> Due to the change in up-wash, down-wash, and wingtip vortices there may be errors in the airspeed system while in ground effect due to changes in the local pressure at the [[Pitot tube|static source]].<ref name="Pilot pp.3-8"/>
Another important issue regarding ground effect is that the makeup of the surface directly affects the intensity; this is to say that a concrete or other smooth hard surface will produce more effect than water or broken ground.{{Citation needed|date=February 2012}}
==Ground-effect vehicle== {{main|Ground-effect vehicle}} Many vehicles have a design that makes use of the wing in ground effect. Although all airplanes fly through ground effect at some point, craft that do so in a dedicated manner are designed in such a way that their wings are normally unable to take them into flight out of ground effect (free flight). Those that can fly out of ground effect are often capable of only a short distance take-off into free flight. Because of this, these craft are often licensed as ships rather than as aircraft. These specially designed craft may use [[delta wing]]s, [[ekranoplan]] wings, or [[tandem wing]]s.

[[File:Honda FCX platform rear Honda Collection Hall.jpg|thumb|250px|A Hydrogen tank on a Honda FCX platform]] A '''Hydrogen tank''' (other names- cartridge or canister) is used for [[hydrogen storage]].<ref>[http://www1.eere.energy.gov/hydrogenandfuelcells/pdfs/ihfpv_proceedings.pdf International hydrogen fuel and pressure vessel forum 2010] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20120905153748/http://www1.eere.energy.gov/hydrogenandfuelcells/pdfs/ihfpv_proceedings.pdf |date=2012-09-05 }}</ref><ref>[http://www1.eere.energy.gov/hydrogenandfuelcells/pdfs/ihfpv_zheng2.pdf R&D of large stationary hydrogen/CNG/HCNG storage vessels]</ref><ref>[http://www1.eere.energy.gov/hydrogenandfuelcells/pdfs/cng_h2_workshop_8_wong.pdf CNG & Hydrogen tank safety, R&D, and testing]</ref> The first type IV hydrogen tanks for [[compressed hydrogen]] at {{convert|700|bar|MPa psi}} were demonstrated in 2001, the first [[fuel cell vehicle]]s on the road with type IV tanks are the [[Toyota FCHV]], [[Mercedes-Benz F-Cell]] and the [[GM HydroGen4]].
==Low-pressure tanks== Various applications have allowed the development of different H2 storage scenarios. Recently, the Hy-Can<ref>[http://www.hydrogen-canister.com/en/ Hycan] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20111206064212/http://www.hydrogen-canister.com/en/ |date=2011-12-06 }}</ref> consortium has introduced a small one liter, {{convert|10|bar|MPa psi}} format. Horizon Fuel Cells is now selling a refillable {{convert|3|MPa|bar psi}} metal hydride form factor for consumer use called HydroStik.<ref>[http://www.horizonfuelcell.com/#!minipak/c156u/ Horizon HydroStik]</ref>
==Type I== * Metal tank (steel/aluminum) * Approximate maximum pressure, aluminum {{convert|175|bar|MPa psi}}, steel {{convert|200|bar|MPa psi}}.
==Type II== * Metal tank (aluminum) with filament windings like [[glass fiber]]/[[aramid]] or [[carbon fiber]] around the metal cylinder.<ref>[http://www.cea.fr/var/cea/storage/static/gb/library/Clefs50/pdf/056a060moysan-gb.pdf Onboard storage of hydrogen-Page 2] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20061127090258/http://www.cea.fr/var/cea/storage/static/gb/library/Clefs50/pdf/056a060moysan-gb.pdf |date=2006-11-27 }}</ref> See [[composite overwrapped pressure vessel]]. * Approximate maximum pressure, aluminum/glass {{convert|263|bar|MPa psi}}, steel/carbon or aramide {{convert|299|bar|MPa psi}}.
==Type III== * Tanks made from [[Composite material|composite]] material, [[fiberglass]]/[[aramid]] or [[carbon fiber]] with a metal liner (aluminum or steel). See [[metal matrix composite]]. * Approximate maximum pressure, aluminum/glass {{convert|305|bar|MPa psi}}, aluminum/aramide {{convert|438|bar|MPa psi}}, aluminium/ carbon {{convert|700|bar|MPa psi}}.
==Type IV== [[File:Hydrogen tanks for Toyota Mirai.png|thumb|right|Hydrogen tanks for the [[Toyota Mirai]].]] * Composite tanks such of carbon fiber with a polymer liner ([[thermoplastic]]). See [[rotational molding]] and [[fibre-reinforced plastic]]. * Approximate maximum pressure {{convert|700|bar|MPa psi}}.<ref>[http://www.storhy.net/train-in/PDF-TI/Poster/Poster_1.pdf Onboard type IV vessels]</ref>
==Type V== * All-composite, linerless Type V tank. CTD has built the first prototype tank for testing January 1, 2014.<ref>[http://www.ctd-materials.com/wordpress/?page_id=1768]</ref><ref>[http://www.compositesworld.com/articles/next-generation-pressure-vessels]</ref>
==Tank testing and safety considerations==
In accordance with ISO/TS 15869 (revised): * Burst test: the pressure at which the tank bursts, typically more than 2x the working pressure. * Proof pressure: the pressure at which the test will be executed, typically above the working pressure. * Leak test or permeation test,<ref>[http://h2storage.net/docs/pdf/29/s4/makarov.pdf Modeling of dispersion following hydrogen permeation for safety engineering and risk assessment] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110723142016/http://h2storage.net/docs/pdf/29/s4/makarov.pdf |date=2011-07-23 }}</ref> in NmL/hr/L (Normal liter of H2/time in hr/volume of the tank. * Fatigue test, typically several thousand cycles of charging/emptying. * Bonfire test where the tank is exposed to an open fire. * Bullet test where live ammunition is fired at the tank.
Actual Standard EC 79/2009 * U.S Department of Energy maintains a hydrogen safety best practices site with a lot of information about tanks and piping.<ref>[http://h2bestpractices.org/storage/ U.S. DOE storage safety]</ref> They dryly observe "Hydrogen is a very small molecule with low viscosity, and therefore prone to leakage.".<ref>[http://h2bestpractices.org/h2properties/ U.S. DOE best safety practices hydrogen properties]</ref>
==Metal hydride storage tank==
===Magnesium hydride=== Using magnesium<ref>[http://neel.cnrs.fr/spip.php?article1281 CNRS Institut Neel H2 Storage]</ref> for [[Hydrogen storage#Metal hydrides|hydrogen storage]], a safe but weighty reversible storage technology. Typically the pressure requirement are limited to {{convert|10|bar|MPa psi}}. The charging process generates heat whereas the discharge process will require some heat to release the H2 contained in the storage material. To activate those type of hydrides, at the current state of development you need to reach approximately {{convert|300|C|F}}. <ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1016/j.scriptamat.2007.01.003| issn = 1359-6462| volume = 56| issue = 10| pages = 841–846| last1 = Dornheim| first1 = M.| last2 = Doppiu| first2 = S.| last3 = Barkhordarian| first3 = G.| last4 = Boesenberg| first4 = U.| last5 = Klassen| first5 = T.| last6 = Gutfleisch| first6 = O.| last7 = Bormann| first7 = R.| title = Hydrogen storage in magnesium-based hydrides and hydride composites| journal = Scripta Materialia| series = Viewpoint set no. 42 “Nanoscale materials for hydrogen storage”| date = 2007}}</ref> <ref>{{Cite journal| doi = 10.1038/35104634| issn = 0028-0836| volume = 414| issue = 6861| pages = 353–358| last1 = Schlapbach| first1 = Louis| last2 = Züttel| first2 = Andreas| title = Hydrogen-storage materials for mobile applications| journal = Nature| date = 2001-11-15}}</ref> <ref>[http://www.mcphy.com/en/index.php Storage by Mc-Phy]</ref>
===Other hydrides===
See also [[sodium aluminium hydride]]
==Research== * 2008 - Japan, a clay-based film sandwiched between prepregs of CFRP.<ref>[http://www.aist.go.jp/aist_e/latest_research/2008/20080617/20080617.html Development of a Clay-Plastic Composite Material with Good Hydrogen Gas Barrier Property] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821113357/http://www.aist.go.jp/aist_e/latest_research/2008/20080617/20080617.html |date=2008-08-21 }}</ref>
==See also== {{col-begin}} {{col-break}} * [[Cascade storage system]] * [[Compressed hydrogen tube trailer]] * [[Cryo-adsorption]] * [[Gas cylinder]] * [[Hydrogen compressor]] * [[Hydrogen safety]] * [[Hydrogen technologies]] {{col-break}} * [[Hydrogen economy]] * [[Liquid hydrogen]] * [[Liquid hydrogen tank truck]] * [[Sodium aluminium hydride]] * [[Magnesium hydride]] * [[Pressure regulator]] {{col-end}}

{{Infobox automobile | name = Italdesign GTZERO | image = Italdesign GTZero Concept Genève 2016 2-2.jpg | caption = GTZERO rear end | manufacturer = [[Italdesign Giugiaro]] | production = 2016 | designer = [[Italdesign Giugiaro]] | class = [[Concept car]] | body_style = 2-door wagon | related = | layout = | motor = 3 electric motors | battery = | electric_range = 310 miles (claimed) | wheelbase = | weight = 4365 lbs (1979.9 kg) (claimed) }}
The Italdesign GTZERO is an electric [[shooting-brake]] concept produced by Italian design company [[Italdesign Giugiaro]] and showcased at the 2016 [[Geneva Motor Show]].<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.motortrend.com/news/italdesign-gtzero-concept-for-geneva-is-a-wild-ev-shooting-brake/|title=Italdesign GTZero Concept for Geneva is a Wild EV Shooting Brake - Motor Trend|date=2016-03-01|newspaper=Motor Trend|language=en-US|access-date=2017-01-09}}</ref>
== Performance == The GTZERO is powered by three [[Electric motor|electric motors]], two in the front and one in the rear, and is [[all-wheel drive]]. The front electric motors produce 148 hp (110 kW) each and the rear motor produces 188 hp (140 kW) for a total of 483 hp (360 kW) and an electronically limited top speed of 155 miles per hour. Italdesign says the car has a range of 310 miles and can recharge to 80 percent capacity in 30 minutes.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.caranddriver.com/news/saved-by-zero-italdesign-unveils-gtzero-concept|title=Italdesign Unveils Electric GTZero Concept – News – Car and Driver|work=Car and Driver|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en}}</ref>
== Features == The GTZERO is built on a modular [[Carbon fibers|carbon fiber]] [[monocoque]], which Italdesign says houses the batteries and allows for multiple body styles to be used. The chassis also features aluminum front and rear subframes. a lightweight composite body, [[butterfly doors]] and [[four wheel steering]] with 5 degrees of steering angle.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.autoblog.com/2016/03/02/italdesign-gtzero-concept-geneva-2016/|title=Italdesign GTZero Concept: An eclectic electric shooting brake|work=Autoblog|access-date=2018-04-08|language=en}}</ref> The interior features configurable seating which can be changed from a 2+2 to a 3+1 arrangement as well as multiple touchscreens to control interior functions.<ref name=":0" />

{{context|date=May 2009}}
'''Mutation Sensation''' is a [[recycling]] project based on reusing discarded “[[stuffed animals]]” toys.
The concept has become an evolutionary project that reconstructs the way people think about the [[market economy]] in reference to mass production (of toys, in this case) which symbolizes the early education of abundance as pleasure. It is also awakening an avenue that opens eyes to the possibilities of alternative equal rights relations between the producers and the consumers of the world. With respect to the inequality of the market, the 1st Mutation Sensation session occurred during a festival under various gamey stipulations such as: long hours, unfavourable work conditions and no pay. It was an intense lesson as to how much work is involved in sewing toys. The Mutations have continued to develop amongst recycling festivals and childhood ecological recycling projects.
Mutation Sensations serve an important demand for performing illusionary transformations and possible elimination of iconographic plush toys into futuristic idealism.
==References== {{reflist}} *(1)https://web.archive.org/web/20110520155054/http://w3.bcn.es/V01/Serveis/Noticies/V01NoticiesLlistatNoticiesCtl/0,2138,1653_1802_2_183775018,00.html?accio=detall&home=HomeBCN *(2) [http://www.basurama.org/b06_moda_limpia_mutation_sensation.htm] Workshop at Basurama *(3)http://www.almazen.net/agenda_web/infos_agenda/somanyprojects.htm{{dead link|date=February 2018 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *(4) http://www.somanyprojects.com * [http://www.instructables.com/id/Mutation_Sensation/ Instructables] * [http://dailydiy.com/2008/12/21/mutation-sensation-2/ DIY] * [http://blog.makezine.com/archive/2009/01/mutation_sensation.html Make Magazine]

[[File:Nuclear Power Plant 2.jpg|thumb|right|200px|A commercial nuclear power plant]]
The '''Nuclear power programme in Pakistan''' started with the Karachi Nuclear Power Plant, also known as [[KANUPP]], inaugurated November 28, 1972. Pakistan is the first [[Muslim world|Muslim country]] in the world to construct and operate civil nuclear power plants.<ref>Nuclear power in Pakistan, Dr. Zia H. Siddiqui and Dr. I.H. Qureshi, pp.31–33.</ref>
== Nuclear Power Programme 2050 ==
The ''Nuclear Power Programme 2050'' is the official nuclear energy policy of the [[Government of Pakistan]] to make usage of [[nuclear power]] to meet the existing [[Electricity in Pakistan|electricity crises]] and to respond to the future requirements of a growing population and [[Economy of Pakistan|national economy]].<ref name="Government of Pakistan"/><ref name="Ministry of Foreign Affairs">{{cite web |title=Official Policy|url=http://www.mofa.gov.pk/mfa/pages/print.aspx?id=1154&type=3|work=Ministry of Foreign Affairs (GOvernment of Pakistan|publisher=Ministry of Foreign Affairs|accessdate=23 November 2012|author=Raza Bashir Tarar, Acting Permanent Representative of Pakistan at the United Nations Security Council Meeting under Agenda Item Maintenance of International Peace and Security}}</ref> The program is envisaged to increase energy production from nuclear sources by the year of 2050.<ref name="Pakistan Tribune">{{cite news|last=Staff|title=Civil nuclear technology: Pakistan wants end to 'discrimination'|url=http://paktribune.com/news/Civil-nuclear-technology-Pakistan-wants-end-to-discrimination-248591.html|accessdate=23 November 2012|newspaper=Pakistan Tribune|date=27 March 2012}}</ref><ref name="Tribune Express">{{cite web|last=Khan|first=Zia|title=Pakistan wants to join Nuclear Suppliers Group|url=http://tribune.com.pk/story/210107/pakistan-wants-to-join-nuclear-suppliers-group/|publisher=Tribune Express|accessdate=23 November 2012|date=July 15, 2011}}</ref> As part of the [[energy security]] strategy, the enactment of the program is aim to expand the self-sustaining nuclear power infrastructure all over the country by year 2050.<ref name="Geo News">{{cite news|last=News Desk|title=NCA okays Nuclear Power Prog 2050, Space Prog 2040|url=http://www.geo.tv/7-14-2011/83707.htm|accessdate=28 November 2012|newspaper=Geo News|date=July 14, 2011}}</ref> It came in a strong response to [[Indo-US civilian nuclear agreement|U.S-India nuclear deal]], as well as to counter the existing energy shortfalls and future requirements of a growing population and national economy.<ref name="Geo News"/> The primary focus of this program is to promote scientific and socio-economic development of the people as a "foremost priority."<ref name="Geo News"/>
The policy was first stated by the former [[Prime Minister of Pakistan|Prime minister]] [[Yousaf Raza Gillani]] during in the meeting of [[Pakistan National Command Authority|Nuclear Command Authority]]; at this meeting, the program was approved by Prime minister Gillani on 14 July 2011.<ref name="Government of Pakistan">{{cite web|last=Government of Pakistan|first=Prime minister Secretariat|title=Opening Remarks by the Prime Minister at the National Command Authority|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:kiYaasGdfXAJ:www.pid.gov.pk/Opening%2520Remarks%2520by%252014-7-2011the%2520PM.doc+pakistan+nuclear+power+programme+2050&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESiKsbJTOW3vQHtY4X4n0iToUVFrcUHP7VAwRoKeQYP_potrTxJL0lWksAZ0TiqYJKUvVH24o_qIRZNduyBs2JAE3JHbHw_vxcvQW0gWmt5yIAC2hZ-VBmeEqv8qlxbTY8A_Koq5&sig=AHIEtbS4chXpihcGOhDsv2CinRyIOHwnLw|work=Pakistan Nuclear Command|publisher=Government of Pakistan|accessdate=23 November 2012|format=google docs|date=14 July 2011}}</ref> This includes to regulate the nuclear facilities, [[Radioactive waste|waste storage]], along with an increase in power plant building. Both legislative, military and bureaucratic regulations of nuclear energy in Pakistan have been shaped by the scientific research and the public opinion.<ref name="Government of Pakistan"/> The governmental nuclear regulatory authorities in Pakistan has projected to produce 4345 MW electricity from nuclear sources in 2022; and 8800 MW electricity by 2030.<ref name="Directorate-General for Nuclear Power Generation">{{cite web|last=Syed Yousaf|first=Raza|title=Current Picture of Electrical Energy In Pakistan|url=https://docs.google.com/viewer?a=v&q=cache:T4QW3douApsJ:www.iaea.org/INPRO/4th_Dialogue_Forum/DAY_3_01_August-ready/2._-_DG-C3-4-31-07-2012.pdf+pakistan+nuclear+power+program+2050&hl=en&gl=us&pid=bl&srcid=ADGEESjUcYBzrkzBdSSwbflDwBpLkLAkFaFROisP_jK3E3S97aqHY9tMS-It6gaYDd-q4lZP8BEuD6e4C5E91EnlkiSKIw-JbWuYsNwjNNC1f1Nxyw9D0Ib_V424k5ghsCazU80qDKfF&sig=AHIEtbRAsJSVdJ36dVxzvdggw_Xz16RLGg|work=Pakistan Atomic Energy Commission|publisher=Directorate-General for Nuclear Power Generation|accessdate=28 November 2012|date=July 31, 2012}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

In [[physics]], the '''pomeron''' is a [[Regge trajectory]] — a family of particles with increasing spin — postulated in 1961 to explain the slowly rising [[Cross section (physics)|cross section]] of [[hadron]]ic collisions at high energies.<ref>Levin, E (1998). [https://arxiv.org/abs/hep-ph/9710546 ''Everything about reggeons.Part I: Reggeons in "soft" interaction''] {{arXiv|hep-ph/9710546}}.</ref> It is named after [[Isaak Pomeranchuk]].
==Overview== While other trajectories lead to falling [[Cross section (physics)|cross sections]], the pomeron can lead to logarithmically rising cross sections — which, experimentally, are approximately constant ones. The identification of the pomeron and the prediction of its properties was a major success of the [[Regge theory]] of [[strong interaction]] phenomenology. In later years, a '''BFKL pomeron'''<ref>E. Levin (1997) [https://arxiv.org/abs/hep-ph/9710546 Course notes]</ref> was derived in further kinematic regimes from perturbative calculations in [[Quantum chromodynamics|QCD]], but its relationship to the pomeron seen in soft high energy scattering is still not fully understood.
One consequence of the pomeron hypothesis is that the cross sections of proton–proton and proton–antiproton scattering should be equal at high enough energies. This was demonstrated by the Soviet physicist [[Isaak Pomeranchuk]] by [[analytic continuation]] assuming only that the cross sections do not fall. The pomeron itself was introduced by [[Vladimir Gribov]], and it incorporated this theorem into [[Regge theory]]. [[Geoffrey Chew]] and [[Steven Frautschi]] introduced the pomeron in the West. The modern interpretation of [[Pomeranchuk's theorem]] is that the pomeron has no conserved charges—the particles on this trajectory have the [[quantum number]]s of the [[Vacuum#Quantum mechanics|vacuum]].
The pomeron was well accepted in the 1960s despite the fact that the measured cross sections of proton–proton and proton–antiproton scattering at the energies then available were unequal.
The pomeron carries no charges. The absence of electric charge implies that pomeron exchange does not lead to the usual shower of [[Cherenkov radiation]], while the absence of [[color charge]] implies that such events do not radiate [[pion]]s.
This is in accord with experimental observation. In high energy proton–proton and proton–antiproton collisions in which it is believed that pomerons have been exchanged, a ''rapidity gap'' is often observed: This is a large angular region in which no outgoing particles are detected.
==Odderon== The odderon, the counterpart of the pomeron that carries odd charge parity was introduced in 1973 by Leszek Łukaszuk and [[Basarab Nicolescu]].<ref>{{cite journal | journal = Lettere al Nuovo Cimento | volume = 8 | issue = 7 | year = 1973 | pages = 405–413 | first1 = Leszek | last1 = Łukaszuk | first2 = Basarab | last2 = Nicolescu | title = A possible interpretation of pp rising total cross-sections | doi=10.1007/bf02824484}}</ref> It was potentially observed only in 2017 by the [[TOTEM experiment]] at the [[LHC]].<ref>{{cite journal | journal = Phys. Lett. B| volume = 778 | year = 2018 | pages = 414–418 | first1 = Evgenij | last1 = Martynov | first2 = Basarab | last2 = Nicolescu | title = Did TOTEM experiment discover the Odderon? | arxiv = 1711.03288 | bibcode = 2018PhLB..778..414M | doi = 10.1016/j.physletb.2018.01.054 }}</ref> Odderon exists in QCD as compound state of 3 [[Regge theory|reggeized]] gluons.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Martynov|first=Evgenij|last2=Nicolescu|first2=Basarab|date=March 2018|title=Did TOTEM experiment discover the Odderon?|url=http://linkinghub.elsevier.com/retrieve/pii/S0370269318300625|journal=Physics Letters B|volume=778|pages=414–418|doi=10.1016/j.physletb.2018.01.054|issn=0370-2693|bibcode=2018PhLB..778..414M}}</ref>
==String theory== In early particle physics, the 'pomeron sector' was what is now called the '[[closed string]] sector' while what was called the '[[reggeon]] sector' is now the '[[Open string (physics)|open string]] theory'.
==See also== *[[Giuseppe Cocconi]] <!--*[[Alan Wetherell]] *[[Bert Diddens]]-->
== References == {{reflist}}
==Further reading== *{{Cite book |author= |year=2003 |title=Pomeron Physics and QCD |arxiv=hep-ph/0312279 |author1=Nachtmann, Otto |doi=10.1142/9789812702722_0023 |journal=New Trends in Hera Physics 2003 |pages=253–267 |bibcode=2004nthp.conf..253N |isbn=978-981-238-835-3 }} *{{cite book | first1 = Sandy | last1 = Donnachie | first2 = H. Günter | last2 = Dosch | first3 = Peter V. | last3 = Landshoff | first4 = Otto | last4 = Nachtmann | title = Pomeron Physics and QCD | publisher = [[Cambridge University Press]] | isbn = 978-0-521-78039-1 | series = Cambridge Monographs on Particle Physics, Nuclear Physics and Cosmology | year = 2002}}
